title: 115_hr1059
content: The term "joint resolution of disapproval" is defined as a resolution by Congress disapproving of the President's proposed action under the Russia Sanctions Review Act of 2017. If such a resolution is enacted, the President is prohibited from waiving, suspending, or limiting sanctions on Russia. During the 120-calendar-day period, a joint resolution of disapproval may be introduced in the House of Representatives by the majority leader or minority leader, and in the Senate by the majority leader or minority leader. If a committee in the House of Representatives does not report the resolution within 10 legislative days, the committee will be discharged. After a joint resolution of disapproval is referred to a committee, it will be discharged if the committee does not report it within 10 legislative days. Once the committee reports or is discharged, the House can move to consider the resolution on the third legislative day. The motion to proceed is not debatable and must be made before the House disposes of a previous motion on the resolution. The joint resolution of disapproval shall be considered as read in the Senate. All points of order are waived, and the resolution will have two hours of debate before final passage. A motion to reconsider the vote on passage is not allowed. The joint resolution of disapproval introduced in the Senate shall be referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. If the committee does not report the resolution within 10 session days, it will be discharged and placed on the calendar. After the committee reports the resolution, it can proceed to consideration in the Senate. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the resolution in the Senate is not debatable and not subject to a motion to postpone. Debate on the joint resolution of disapproval and all debatable motions and appeals will follow if the motion is agreed to. The debate on the joint resolution of disapproval and all debatable motions and appeals shall be limited to 10 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. A motion to further limit debate is allowed. The vote on passage will occur immediately after the debate, with a single quorum call if requested. The Senate rules state that appeals on procedure decisions related to a joint resolution of disapproval shall be decided without debate. Debate on any veto message regarding the resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. The Senate rules outline procedures for joint resolutions of disapproval, including limited debate on veto messages. If one House receives a joint resolution of disapproval from the other House, specific procedures apply. The Senate rules outline procedures for joint resolutions of disapproval, including limited debate on veto messages. If one House fails to introduce a joint resolution of disapproval, the other House's resolution will receive expedited floor procedures. The House of Representatives can pass a joint resolution of disapproval without debate. This rule does not apply to revenue measures. The rules for joint resolutions of disapproval are part of the House and Senate rules and govern the procedure for these resolutions. The House of Representatives can pass a joint resolution of disapproval without debate, which supersedes other rules to the extent of inconsistency. The constitutional right of either House to change rules relating to its procedure is recognized. Definitions include the term "appropriate congressional committees and leadership" referring to specific committees and leaders. The term "United States person" refers to a US citizen, lawful permanent resident, or an entity organized under US laws. It involves specific committees and leaders in the House and Senate.
